title: 113_hr3347
content: The Act is titled the "Disaster Assistance Transparency and Accountability Act of 2013" or the "DATA Act of 2013". It includes provisions for disaster assistance reports. The "Disaster Assistance Transparency and Accountability Act of 2013" requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to submit a report to Congress within 180 days of enactment. The report must detail the amount of Federal Government spending on disaster assistance for the 10 most recent fiscal years, specifying the obligations made by each department or agency and under each relevant program. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must submit an annual report to Congress detailing the projected amount of Federal Government spending on disaster assistance for the fiscal year, specifying obligations by each department or agency and under each relevant program. The Office of Management and Budget must report to Congress the projected amount of disaster assistance obligations for each Federal department or agency and relevant programs for the fiscal year. The Office of Management and Budget must report to Congress the amount obligated for disaster assistance by each Federal department or agency and their relevant programs, projects, or activities for the most-recently concluded fiscal year. Additionally, corrections to previously submitted reports under this subsection must be included. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report every 2 years to Congress evaluating Federal disaster assistance spending, recommending improvements for transparency and accountability, and assessing the effectiveness and equity of the current cost-sharing system. The Comptroller General evaluates Federal disaster assistance spending every 2 years, focusing on effectiveness in reducing costs and promoting non-Federal investment in disaster recovery, mitigation, and preparedness. Definitions for "disaster" and "disaster assistance" are provided in this section. Federal disaster assistance refers to any Federal activity, including financial aid, aimed at helping a public or private entity affected by a disaster.
